Yaw will use the loan to purchase a bale of male trousers and introduce shirt sales. With the new profits from his expanded business, Yaw plans to save and reinvest into his business.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of male trousers and introduce shirt sales.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a 40-year-old married woman with 8 children. She plans to plant agricultural products such as pyrethrum, potatoes, peas, and maize. She is appylying for a loan of KES 20,000 to buy seeds for potatoes, peas, maize, and pyrethrum. This is her first loan application through SMEP DTM, and thus would enhance the growth of her business. She sees herself in the near future having bought enough land to supply her members in Nakuru town with enogh food produce.

loans.use: to buy seeds for  potatoes, peas, maize, and pyrethrum.

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en:
Meet 40-year-old Memunatu from the Lunsar Northern area in Sierra Leone. She is married with four children between the ages of nine and 20. Three of her children are currently attending school. Memunatu established her general store in 2009 to create income to improve her standard of living. She works seven days a week, 15 hours a day. Memunatu's major business challenge is transportation.

Memunatu is requesting a loan to buy more soap, milk, toothpaste, and sardines. She hopes that the extra income from her loan will allow her to take good care of her family. In the future, Memunatu plans to build a permanent residence for her family. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy soap, milk, toothpaste, and sardines

loans.name: Joynab

texts.en:
This is 32-year-old Joynab from the Lunsar Northern area in Sierra Leone. She is divorced with three children between the ages of 10 and 17. Her children are currently attending school. Since 1993, Joynab has run a general store in her community where she sells rum, biscuits, pure water, and soft drinks. She works every day, 11 hours per day. Joynab's major business challenges are the poor road network and her insufficient capital.

Joynab is requesting a loan to buy more rum, biscuits, pure water, and soft drinks. She will use the extra income from her loan to educate her children and take good care of her family. In the future, Joynab plans to build a house and send her children to university. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy rum, biscuits, pure water, and soft drinks

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Meet 38-year-old Isatu from Port Loko in the Northern area in Freetown. She is married with four children between the ages of 8 and 18. Her children are currently attending school. 

In 2003, Isatu established her salon business. She began her business because, after she graduated from a vocational training school, she decided to start her business to create income, to support her family. She works at the business based on customers' demand. At present, she describes her major problem to be inadequate material available to use in the salon when customers want to do a certain style.

Isatu requires a loan in order to buy more varieties of hair and hair cream to expand her salon. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to expand her business and pay fees for her children. In the future, she plans to open a permanent business site. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more varieties of hair and hair cream to expand her salon.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Meet 36-year-old Isatu from Port Loko northern area in Sierra Leone. She is married with four children between the ages of five and 11. Her children are currently attending school. In 2006, Isatu established her general store business. She began her business because she was trained in business and she thinks it is profitable. She works at the business 12 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is the price inflation of goods.

Isatu requires a loan in order to purchase more soap, rice, sugar, and drinks. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her standard of living and pay her children’s school fees. In the future, Isatu plans to buy a plot of land. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more soap, rice, sugar, and drinks.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian operates a local chop bar at Hohoe lorry station. She cooks and sells banku and fufu, local Ghanaian dishes. In Ghana, fufu is mostly made from boiled cassava and unripe plantain beaten together. Fufu (also known as foofoo or foufou) is a thick paste usually made by boiling starchy root vegetables in water and pounding with a mortar and pestle until the desired consistency is reached. The malleable dough is served and eaten with a light tomato soup, groundnut soup, palm oil fruit soup or other soups. Banku/Akple is fermented corn/cassava dough mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water into a smooth whitish consistent paste. Served with soup, stew or a pepper sauce with fish. The most popular side dish for banku in Ghana is okra stew.  

Vivian is single but has 3 children. She has been in business for the past 9 years. She is responsible for the general upkeep of herself and three other dependents. Her loan will be used to buy bags of maize, palm fruits, cassava dough, bags of cassava, plantains, meat, and varieties of fish. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards her old age.

loans.use: to buy bags of maize, palm fruits, cassava dough, bags of cassava, plantains, meat, and varieties of fish.

loans.name: Magrate

texts.en: Magrate is a 27-year-old married woman with 3 children. She is a fish vendor in Nakuru with the motive of starting a hotel which mainly focuses on a sushi menu. This is her second succesful loan with SMEP DTM. She describes herself as determined to succeed. She will use the 40,000 to buy fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy fish.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a married woman with 3 children. Grace sells bathing sponges, twine, and drying rope near Hohoe lorry station, which she has done to support herself and husband for 6 years now. Her husband is a petty trader. Grace uses her income to assist her husband to feed the home and cater for their children. Grace will use the loan to purchase bundles of rope in different sizes and a variety of sponges. With the new profits from her expanded business, Grace plans to save and acquire a shop.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of rope in different sizes and a variety of sponges.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
This is 35-year-old Kadiatu from the Port Loko Northern area in Sierra Leone. She is married with five children between the ages of one and 18. Three of her children are going to school. Since 2002, Kadiatu has run a business selling different kinds of used clothing. She works throughout the week, 12 hours per day. Kadiatu says that her main business challenges is the slow purchasing power of her customers during the rainy season. 

Kadiatu is requesting a loan to buy more used clothing to sell. The extra income from her loan will allow her to take good care of her family. In the future, Kadiatu plans to open a used clothing shop. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy used clothing to sell

loans.name: Neneh

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 21-year-old Neneh from the Port Loko northern area in Freetown. She is a married mother blessed with a six-month old child. Since 2011, Neneh has been running a business where she sells different kinds of slippers. Since she did not go to school, she began her business to have a permanent source of income to support her family. Neneh works every day from morning to night. She says that her business is doing well and she has daily sales above 200,000 SLL each day.   

Neneh is requesting a loan to buy a variety of slippers. The extra income from her loan will allow her to repay her loan installments and buy a generator to improve her house. In the future, Neneh plans to build a permanent residence. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy slippers to sell

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Afi est une femme âgée de 37 ans. Elle est mariée å un gendarme. Elle mère de famille. Afi travaille comme revendeuse depuis 1998. Elle vend des céréales pour tous clients au marché. Elle achète les produits à Lomé. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, sa difficulté principale est la rupture de stock. Afi a requis son troisième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des céréales. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. Dans les prochaines années, Afi voudrait constituer une réserve de céréales qu’elle pourra revendre pendant les périodes de soudure. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit de subvenir à tous les besoins de sa famille.
texts.en: Afi is a 37 year old woman. She is married to a policeman. She is a mother. Afi has been working as a reseller since 1998. She sells cereals to all types of customers at the market. She buys her products in Lomé. She works alone. At the moment, her main difficulty is stock shortages. Afi requested her third loan from WAGES in order to buy cereals. She wants to reinvest in her business. In the coming years, Afi would like to build up a reserve of cereals that she will be able to resell during periods of shortage. She says that with the profits, she plans to meet all the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy cereals.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is a married man aged 37 years. He has six children aged 18, 16, 10, 9, 7 and 4 years, and out of these children only three attend school. Vincent operates a business dealing in the sale of a local brew commonly known as waragi, and it is his major source of income to look after the family. He also practices agriculture but on a smaller scale as an additional source of income.

Vicent wants a loan of 1,000,000 (one million shillings) to complete his residential house under construction so that his family can have decent living conditions. Vincent's dream is to educate his children up to high institutions of learning.

However, his major challenge is the poor road network, most especially when it rains, which makes transportation of his waragi to market very difficult.

In the photograph is the loan officer at the forefront and the client at the back. This is the house Vincent wants to complete.

loans.use: to complete his residential house.

loans.name: Rospah

texts.en: Rospah is a focused 37-year-old married woman with six children. She applying for a KES 30,000 loan through SMEP DTM to expand her cereal stock for her posho mill. She sees herself in the near future as processing flour and supplying it to residents in Nakuru. She is also a farmer who plants food crops to sustain her family.

loans.use: to stock cereals at her posho mill.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a married man. He has 2 children. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a butchery where he sells meat. He has been involved in this business for 4 years. His business is located in an urban area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be capital to expand the business. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to to open another butchery business. He hopes that in the future, he will be prosperous. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to open another butchery business.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a 25-year-old married man with a child. He describes himself as an honest and faithful man. He is applying for a loan of KES 20,000 through SMEP DTM. This is his second loan. He plans to purchase fertilizer and seeds so as to farm crops to enable him sustain his family. He sees himself in five years as expanded and owning more land for farming.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 32-year-old Fatmata, from Port Loko. She is married to a teacher and has three children between the ages of 4 and 14. Her children are currently going to school. Her business income is not enough to support the home. 

Fatmata sells general stock items at her house. She sells soap, milk, pure water, and sweets. She has been running this business since 2006. She works at the business throughout the week, from morning to night. Fatmata says that her business is going well because she started with a small amount through BRAC Sierra Leone Microfinance Company Limited.

Fatmata has requested a loan to buy more soap, milk, pure water, and sweets. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children. In the future, she plans to open a big shop. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more soap, milk, pure water, and sweets to sell.

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
This is Cristita, 57, resident of Tondo, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Joel, her business partner, and a father to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses. 
 
Cristita operates a meat stall. She buys slaughtered hogs, cuts them into smaller portions, then sells them per kilo. There are many patrons who prefer her products since they are assured of their freshness and cleanliness. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 in sales, every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 19,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies of pork, needed in her business. 

Cristita dreams to expand her business and have her own stall in the market. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for pork that she can sell per kilo.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizers.

loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en:
Meet 35-year-old Mabinty from Waterloo eastern area in Freetown. She is married with 4 children between the ages of 8 and 17. Her children are currently attending school. In 1998, Mabinty established her general stock business. She began her business because she needs to create a permanent source of income to support the home. She works at the business throughout the week, 12 hours per day. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

Mabinty requires a loan in order to buy more books, biscuits and sugar. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and increase her business. In the future, Mabinty plans to expand her business to a big shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more books, biscuits and sugar.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
Abibatu is 25 years old and married with one child aged five. She runs a clothing business in Port Loko in the northern area of Sierra Leone.

She's been in this business for three years and sells waxed cotton and slippers.  She says that the main challenge to her business is low purchasing power during rainy season.

Abibatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy more waxed cotton and slippers. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her support her child and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy more waxed cotton and slippers.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
This is 40-year-old Emma from Port Loko in the northern area of Sierra Leone. She is married and has four children between the ages of three and 15. Her children are currently attending school

Emma runs a bakery business; she sells cake and bread. She has been running this business since 2009. She works at the business throughout the week. Her business is the only income she has. She says that the main challenge to her business that the heat of the oven sometimes disturbs her health.

Emma has requested a loan in order to buy sugar, cooking oil and flour to resell. The extra income from this loan will allow her to take care of herself and her family. In the future, she plans to open a big shop and pay her children’s school fees up to university. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy sugar, cooking oil and flour to resell.

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Meet 40-year-old Mariatu from Port Loko in the northern area of Sierra Leone. She is married with three children and has four additional dependents that live with her because they are relatives. 

In 2002, Mariatu established her general store business. She began her business because she needs to create income to support the home. She works at the business every day, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

Mariatu requires a loan in order to buy more body cream, soap and assorted drinks. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business so she can attract customers and improve her family. In the future, Mariatu plans to import her goods from a neighboring area. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more body cream, soap and assorted drinks.

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu is 35 years old and married with four children, ages five and 16. She runs a cookery business in Port Loko in the northern part of Sierra Leone. 

She's been in this business for three years and sells cooked rice. She says that her business is doing well because out of the proceeds, she is able to feed her children.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy rice, palm oil dry fish and cooking seasoning. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to buy a table and increase her business. In the future, she would like to open a permanent business location to operate her business. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy rice, palm oil, dry fish and cooking seasoning.

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
This is Romeo. He previously accessed a PHP 23,000 loan that he used to purchase quantities of raw materials, like fabric, thread, and other materials needed in his business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in their personal, household, and business expenditures.

Romeo would like to apply for another PHP 27,000 loan to buy additional supplies of raw materials, like fabric, cloth, thread, and other materials needed in his business. His profits from business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs and his children’s education. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Romeo dreams to have a stall in the market, to be easily seen by customers, and he hopes that his children will finish their studies. Every week, he meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that he studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for fabric, cloth, thread, and other materials needed in his business.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio is a 61-year-old, married man, with eight children, from Gubaan, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. Rogelio cultivates a rice farm. He has been cultivating rice for 13 years and earns PHP 15,000 a month in this business. 

In 2007, Rogelio joined Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC). He is requesting a loan of PHP 21,000 which will be used to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for the next cropping. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for his rice farm.

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les quatre femmes du groupe  BENKAN  ont  en moyenne 43 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village Santoro de San  dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités professionnelles et de parenté. Elles font l’achat et la vente de légumes, d’habits de poissons et de la restauration. 
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles de plus en plus nombreuses et exigeantes, les membres du groupe ont décidé  d’intégrer  le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  12eme  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux précédents.
Madame,   MAIMOUNA  présidente de l’association (2 eme de la droite vers la gauche) excelle la vente de Bazin riche et wax. Elle est très sollicitée dans le quartier et au grand marché. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 50 pièces de wax ,4 pièces de Bazin riches  à Bamako.  Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle mixtes. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame  MAIMOUNA  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 70000 FCFA  qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et  aider son conjoint dans la prise en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Married mainly in traditional extended families, the four women of the group BENKAN are on average 43 years old and have 6 children. They all live in the town of Santoro de San in the region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali) and met through neighborhood, professional business and family ties. They buy and sell vegetables, clothing, fish and do catering. With the goal of satisfying the needs of their clientele which is more and more numerous and demanding, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 12th loan in solidarity, after having correctly repaid the two previous loans.

Madam Maimouna, president of the association (2nd from the right to the left) excels in the sale of rich and wax damask fabrics. She is very much in demand in her neighborhood and at the large market.

She plans to use her loan to buy 50 pieces of wax damask fabrics and 4 pieces of rich damask fabrics in Bamako. She carries out her sales for cash, retail and for credit to a mixed clientele.

With this loan, Madam Maimouna hopes to make an average monthly profit of 70,000 FCFA which will be used to be reinvested in her business and to help her spouse in taking care of the needs of the home.

loans.use: to buy a variety of items.

loans.name: Veronica Alexandra

texts.es:
Alexandra  tiene  32 años de edad es soltera tiene un hijo vive con su madre  en  el Cantón Chillanes 

Provincia Bolívar.



Alexandra se dedica al negocio de ropa. 


Solicita el crédito para la compra  de ropa y así poder aumentar su negocio.    



Las compras lo realizan en la ciudad de Chillanes.  



Su sueño es tener su vivienda propia.  



El desafío que enfrenta es la falta de capital.   



En el tiempo libre le gusta leer.
texts.en:
Alexandra is 32 years old, single, and has a son that lives with her mother in Chillanes canton, Bolívar province.

Alexandra has a clothing business. She is requesting a loan to buy clothes in the city of Chillanes and expand her business.

Alexandra’s dream is to have her own house. She faces the challenge of lack of capital. During her free time, she likes to read.

loans.use: to buy clothes to expand her business.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio, a farmer from the village of Sto. Niňo, Angadanan, is 58 years old, married and has eight children. For almost seven years, he has been supporting his family through his food vending business, usually selling fried snacks such as banana que and camote que, as well as hot dogs and pineapple juice.

Antonio has requested this loan of PHP 18,000 to buy bananas, hot dogs, potato curls and pineapple juice to sell. He hopes that he can get the amount requested in order to further develop his business.

loans.use: to buy bananas, hot dogs, potato curls and pineapple juice to sell.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is a resident of Tondo, Manila, Philippines. She is 53 years old and is happily married to Constancio who works as a family driver. God has blessed them with four loving children. Life indeed is hard. But by the grace of God, they were able to raise their children well and they are helping each other in working for their family.

Luzviminda owns a variety store. This is a small store that can be owned by anyone in the community and the store is just connected to or just inside their houses. This is where you can buy a sachet of shampoo or conditioner, a bar of soap, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg and other items. She gets her product from a wholesaler at a lower price then she will sell them per piece for a higher price to have profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors, passersby and the people in the community. She earns 300 PHP a day.

To be able to expand her inventory, she is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. This loan will be a great help for her to add more products to her store.

Luzviminda hopes to expand and dreams to have another stall in the market. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Celma

texts.en:
This is Celma. She previously accessed a 17,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 18,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Celma dreams for continuous success in her business. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Arlete

texts.pt:
Casada e mãe de 4 filhos que frequentam Escola, vive na casa própria e não sustenta mais ninguém.
É auxiliar no Ministério de saúde e com o presente empréstimo pretende comprar material de construção (blocos, cimento, areia, ferro, pedra e outros) para dar continuidade a obra da sua casa. 
No futuro deseja concluir a sua casa, voltar a estudar e incentivar os filhos a continuar com os estudos, para tal compromete-se a pagar devidamente o empréstimo para solicitar mais a Hluvuku. 
O desafio é trabalhar mais para crescer profissionalmente e receber mais.
texts.en:
Arlete is married and the mother of 4 children who go to School; lives in a house she owns and doesn't support anyone else.

She's an assistant at the Ministry of Health. With this loan she plans to buy construction material (blocks, cement, sand, iron, stone and others) to continue the building work on her home.

In future Arlete hopes to complete her house, go back to school and encourage her children to continue with their studies. To this end, she commits to duly paying off the loan so as to solicit further loans from Hluvuku.

Her challenge is to work harder in order to grow professionally and increase her income.

loans.use: buy construction material (blocks, cement, sand, iron, stone and others) to continue the building work on her home.

loans.name: Miriya Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les sept femmes du groupe  MIRIYA   ont  en moyenne 38 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Santoro I de SAN  dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités professionnelles et de parenté. Elles font l’achat et la vente de diverses marchandises et bois de chauffage. 
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles de plus en plus croissantes  et exigeantes, les membres du groupe ont décidé  d’intégrer  le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  1er  prêt solidaire.
Madame AWA (2e debout de la droite vers la gauche  sur la photo) excelle dans la vente de bois de chauffe. Elle est très sollicitée dans son quartier
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, un chargement de remorque de bois de chauffage. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail  à une clientèle mixtes. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame AWA espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et  aider son conjoint dans la prise en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Married mainly in traditional extended families, the seven women of the group MIRIYA are on average 38 years old and have 5 children. They all live in the Santoro I de San neighborhood in the region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali) and met through neighborhood, professional business and family ties. They buy and sell a variety of merchandise and firewood.

With the goal of satisfying the needs of their more and more numerous and demanding clientele, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first loan in solidarity.

Madam Awa (2nd standing from the right to the left in the photo) excels in the sale of firewood. She is very much in demand in her neighborhood. She plans to use her loan to buy a trailer load of firewood. She carries out her sales for cash, retail and to a mixed clientele.

With this loan Madam Awa hopes to make an average monthly profit of 11,000 FCFA which will be used to reinvest in her business and to help her spouse to take care of the needs of the home.

loans.use: to buy firewood.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is 35 years old and she is now applying for a loan of 1,000 USD to improve her business. She opened her kiosk in 2007 with her own working capital of 50 USD. She earns a good income from her business. Paulina is a very hardworking woman and doing business has become her regular activity for the past 6 years. Her husband is a teacher.

Paulina will use her loan to buy some stock to keep in her store such as body lotion, noodles, cigarettes, milk, coffee, sugar, break soft drinks, hard drinks, beer and rice. She wants to make her business bigger and improve her living conditions in the future.

loans.use: To buy body lotion, noodles, cigarettes, milk, coffee, sugar, break soft drinks, hard drinks beer and rice.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is a resident of Tondo, Manila, Philippines. She is 42 years old. She is happily married to Silverio and God has blessed them with loving children. Life, indeed, is hard. But by the grace of God, they were able to raise their children well and they are helping each other in working for their family.

Norma owns a variety store. This is a small store that can be owned by anyone in the community and the store is just connected to or just inside their houses. This is where you can buy a sachet of shampoo or conditioner, a bar of soap, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg and other items. Norma gets her products from a wholesaler at a lower price then she will sell the products, per piece, for a higher price to create a profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors, passerbys, and the people in the community. She earns PHP 300 per day.

To be able to expand her inventory, Norma is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. This loan will be a great help to her in adding more products to her store.

Norma dreams that her business will continue to grow and she hopes that her children will finish their studies. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita is 54 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She owns and operates a farm to earn a living. She has been in her business for over 10 years and earns 8,000 PHP every month. She joined GDMPC in the year 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure.  In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
This is Trinidad, 57, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Ananias, a worker and is a mother to her children. Together with her children, she manages the household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses. 
 
Trinidad operates a food stall. She sells different snacks like corn, turnips, bananas, mangos and other products. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy corn, bananas, mangos and other products needed in her business. 

Trinidad hopes that her business will expand soon and dreams of having a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like corn, bananas, mangos and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Fatmata    G

texts.en:
Fatmata, 27, is from Port Loko in the northern area of Sierra Leone. She is married and has two children who are between the ages of two and five.

Fatmata runs a clothing business selling trousers, shirts, and blouses. She has been running this business for five years. She works twelve hours per day, seven days per week. She says that her business is growing because she got a small loan from BRAC. To date, she has taken out three loans.

Fatmata is requesting a loan in order to buy more trousers, shirts, and blouses. The extra income she will earn as a result of this loan will allow her to expand her business and educate her children. In the future, she plans to open a big boutique. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more trousers, shirts, and blouses.

loans.name: Manilyn

texts.en: Manilyn is 29 years old, married with 2 children. She lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She owns and operates a food vending stall where she sells things like like sea shells in the local community to earn a living. She has been in her business for over 3 years and earns 15,000 PHP every month. She joined GDMPC in the year 2012. And now she has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to purchase additional sea shells to sell.  In the future, She wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional sea shells to sell.

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en: Ivy is 33 years old, married with 4 children. She lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She plants and harvests vegetable for sale in the local community to earn a living. She has been in her business for over 5 years and earns 15,000 PHP every month for doing this kind of business. She has joined GDMPC in the year 2007, and now she has requested a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure.  In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Saturnino

texts.en:
Saturnino is 62 years old, married and has four children. He lives in Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He owns and operates a pedicab, providing transportation, to earn a living. He has been in this business for over six years and earns 1,500 PHP every month. 

He joined in GDMPC in the year 2011, and now he has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase new tires so as to give a better service. In the future, he wants to make improvements to his house and to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase new tires so as to give a better service.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
A $USD 600 loan is offered to Josefina to improve her business. Josefina opened her kiosk in 2009 with her own working capital of $USD 100. She will use the loan to buy stock to keep in her store like oil, slippers, fish, noodles, milk, water, coffee and sugar.

She is generating a good income from selling. She has been thinking of running a bigger business after years of involving herself in doing business. She is living in a town with her family.

loans.use: To buy oil, fish, noodles, milk, water, snacks, cigarettes, coffee, sugar and slippers.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is 30 years old, married and has one child. He lives in Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He owns and operates a motorcycle transport service in the local community to earn a living. He has been in his business for over three years and earns 15,000 PHP every month. 

He joined in GDMPC in the year 2011, and now he has requested a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase spare parts and tires so as to give a better service.  In the future, he wants to make improvements to his house and to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and tires so as to give a better service.

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en:
Merlie is 56 years old, married and has two children. She lives in Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates farmland, planting and harvesting rice for sale in the local community to earn a living. She has been in her business for over eight years and earns 40,000 PHP every month. 

She joined in GDMPC in the year 2008 and now she has requested a loan of 50,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. In the future she wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Imelda Del Carmen

texts.es:
Imelda, requiere de un nuevo préstamo por la necesidad de invertir más en el negocio de venta de pupusas; este le ayudara a reparar el lugar donde vende el producto, comprar maíz, aceite y todo lo necesario  para elaborar las pupusas.
El crédito anterior le permitió mejorar sus ventas e incrementar sus inventarios; las circunstancias familiares se han optimizado y las condiciones económicas han mejorado, ya que tiene más amueblada la casa.
texts.en:
Imelda needs a new loan because she needs to invest more in her business of selling pupusas [Salvadoran stuffed tortillas].  This will help her to repair the place where she sells the product, and to buy corn, oil and everything necessary to make pupusas.  

The previous loan allowed her to improve her sales and increase her inventory.  Her family circumstances have been optimized and economic conditions have improved, since her house is more furnished.

loans.use: to repair the place where she sells her product, and to buy corn, oil and everything necessary to make pupusas.

loans.name: Wassa Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les 5 femmes du groupe mougnou  ont  en moyenne 41ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village de DALLAN de SAN  dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et de parenté. Elles font la restauration, et la vente de divers articles. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe  intègrent  Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  1er prêt solidaire.
Madame, FATOUMATA (1 ère personne debout  de la gauche  vers la droite) très connue dans la vente d’habits
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 10 pièces de pagnes. Elle s’approvisionne  auprès des grossistes à SAN. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, a une clientèle d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame FATOUMATA espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
All of them married in traditional extended families, the five women of the group Mougnou average 41 years of age and six children each. The women all live in the village of DALLAN de SAN, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali), and they know one another through ties of community, marriage, and kinship. They work in food service and sell a variety of items.

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan.  

Ms. FATOUMATA (first person standing from the left in the photo) is well-known for selling clothing. She intends to use her loan to purchase 10 lengths of 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa). She gets her supplies from SAN wholesalers. She makes her sales in cash to a customer base composed of men and women. 

With this loan, Ms. FATOUMATA hopes to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting household needs.

loans.use: to purchase 'pagne' cloth

loans.name: Jose Maria

texts.es:
José  tiene 34 años de edad es soltero vive con sus padres en Cantón Chillanes Provincia de Bolívar. 



Es integrante de ventanilla Unión Central Parroquia San José del  Tambo actividad económica agricultura, 

crianza de animales  y comercio la comunidad se encuentra a una hora de la cooperativa.



José se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de cacao. 



Solicita el crédito para la compra de cacao para la siembra y para la incrementación de  los huertos cacao.


La compra lo realiza en San José  del Tambo. 



El sueño es el arreglo de casa y comprar un carro. 




No se enfrenta a ningún desafío. 




En el tiempo libre le gusta descansar y andar en moto.
texts.en:
José is 34 years old and single.  He lives with his parents in Chillanes Canton, Bolívar Province.  He is a member of the Unión Central Parroquia San José del Tambo communal bank, which includes businesses in agriculture, animal husbandry and trade.  The community is located an hour from the cooperative.

José makes his living in agriculture, planting cacao.  He is applying for a loan to buy cacao for planting and for expanding his cacao plots.  He makes his purchases in San José del Tambo.

His dream is to repair his house and to buy a car.  He doesn't face any challenges.  In his free time, he likes to rest and ride his motorcycle.

loans.use: to buy cacao for planting and for expanding his cacao plots.

loans.name: Fatmata     M

texts.en:
Fatmata, 34, is from Port Loko. She is married and has two children between the ages of 10 and 15. Her children attend school. 

Fatmata runs a general store at her house. She sells palm oil, rice, milk, cigarettes, and cooking oil. She has been running this business since 1992. She works at her business throughout the week, from morning to night. Currently, her business is doing well.

Fatmata is requesting a loan in order to buy more food commodities such as palm oil, rice, milk, cigarettes, and cooking oil for her store. The extra income she will earn as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her business and provide for her family. In the future, she plans to educate her children at the university-level. 

She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more food commodities such as palm oil, rice, milk, cigarettes, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza, from Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur, is 33 years old, married, and has two children. To make a living, she has been planting and harvesting rice for sale for four years, earning 15,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Liza joined GDMPC and is now requesting a loan of 35,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for her next crop. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for her next crop.

loans.name: Sebeallahye Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les sept femmes du groupe   SEBEALLAHYE  ont  en moyenne 40 ans et  5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Lafiabougou  cercle de SAN  dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et de parenté. Elles font l’achat et la vente  de condiments, et divers articles. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  1er prêt solidaire.
Madame, RAMATA  (2 eme personne debout  de la droite vers la gauche) compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une grande quantité de divers condiments  auprès des grossistes de SAN. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’homme, à domicile. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame RAMATA  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 8000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
All of them married in traditional extended families, the seven women of the group SEBEALLAHYE average 40 years of age and five children each. The women all live in the Lafiabougou district, in Cercle de SAN, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali), and they know one another through ties of community, marriage, and kinship. They buy and sell condiments and a variety of items.

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan.  

Ms. RAMATA (second person standing from the right in the photo) intends to use her loan to purchase a large quantity of various condiments from SAN wholesalers. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales retail at her house. Her customer base is composed of men and women. 

With this loan, Ms. RAMATA hopes to make an average monthly profit of 8,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting household needs.

loans.use: to purchase condiments to sell

loans.name: Nibia Leticia

texts.es:
Leticia  tiene 41 años de edad  es soltera tiene tres hijos  vive con sus hijos en el Cantón Chillanes

Provincia Bolívar.



Es integrante de ventanilla Unión Central Parroquia San José del  Tambo actividad económica agricultura, 

crianza de animales  y comercio la comunidad se encuentra a una hora de la cooperativa.



 Leticia se dedica a la agricultura como  a la siembra  de cacao. 



Solicita el crédito para la limpieza de las huertas y  para que haya más producción.   


Las compras lo realizan  en la ciudad de Babahoyo.  



Su sueño es ponerse un negocio propio.   




No tiene desafíos que enfrentar.  




En su tiempo libre le gusta escuchar  música.
texts.en:
Leticia is single, 41 years old and lives with her three children in Chillanes canton in Bolívar province.

She is a member of the "Unión Central" cooperative in San José del  Tambo parish; they farm, raise livestock and trade. The community  is located one hour from the cooperative.

Leticia works as a farmer, growing crops such as cacao.

She is seeking a loan in order to be able to clean up her fields and increase production.   

She buys supplies in the city of Babahoyo.  

Her dream is to open her own business.   

She is not facing any challenges.  

In her free time she likes to listen to music.

loans.use: to clean up her fields and increase production.

loans.name: Mery  Cumanda

texts.es:
Mery  tiene 44 años de edad es casada y tiene tres hijos vive con su esposo  y sus hijos en el   Cantón 

Chillanes Provincia Bolívar.



Es integrante de ventanilla Unión Central Parroquia San José del  Tambo actividad económica agricultura, 

crianza de animales  y comercio la comunidad se encuentra a una hora de la cooperativa.



Mery se dedica a la agricultura y a la siembra de cacao.  




Solicita el crédito para la limpieza de las huertas de cacao. 

 


Las compras se realizan en la ciudad de Babahoyo.  



Su sueño es poner un negocio propio.
 


No tiene ningún desafío que enfrentar.  


En el tiempo libre le gusta  realizar queseares en la casa.
texts.en:
Mery, 44, is married and has three children.  She lives with her husband and children in Chillanes Canton in the province of Bolívar.

She's a member of Unión Central Communal Bank in the parish of San José del Tambo, where the economic activities are agriculture, raising animals, and trade.  The community is located an hour from the cooperative.

Mery makes a living in agriculture growing cacao.  She's requesting the loan to weed her cacao fields.  She makes her purchases in the city of Babahoyo.

Her dream is to set up her own business.  She faces no challenges.  In her free time she likes to do housework.

loans.use: to weed her cacao fields

loans.name: Estanislao

texts.es:
Estanislao, vive con su familia y se dedica a vender zapatos como una fuente generadora de ingresos para los gastos del hogar y todo lo referente a la familia. El requiere optar por un  préstamo por la necesidad de  invirtir en el negocio para así obtener mayores ganancias; este le permitirá comprar zapatos para damas y niños.
Su sueños es  incrementar sus inventarios, obtener mejores ingresos y mejorar las  condiciones económicas  y las circunstancias familiares.
texts.en:
Estanislao lives with his family and makes his living selling shoes as a source for generating income for household expenses and for everything related to the family.

He needs a loan because he needs to invest in his business in order to increase his earnings.  This would allow him to buy shoes for women and children.  

His dream is to increase his inventory, earn a better income and improve his economic conditions and family circumstances.

loans.use: to buy shoes for women and children.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les quatre  femmes du groupe Djiguiya ont  en moyenne 45 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier  Dallan de San dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles font l’achat et la vente de  diverses marchandises.  Les membres du groupe sont à leur  5eme   prêt solidaire.
Madame, ASSA  (1ere femme debout de la droite vers la gauche) excelle dans la vente de tissus wax. Elle est très sollicitée dans la ville de  SAN et ses environnants. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter,  15 pièces de pagnes auprès des grossistes de SAN. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame ASSA  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et  aider son conjoint dans la prise en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
All of them married in traditional extended families, the four women of the group Djiguiya average 45 years of age and five children each. The women all live in the Dallan de San district, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali), and they know one another through ties of community and kinship. They buy and sell a variety of merchandise. The group members are on their fifth solidarity loan.

Ms. ASSA (first woman standing from the right in the photo) excels in selling Wax cloth. She is much in demand in and around SAN City. She intends to use her loan to purchase 15 lengths of 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa) from SAN wholesalers. Accepting cash, she makes her sales retail to a customer base is composed of men and women. 

With this loan, Ms. ASSA hopes to make an average monthly profit of 22,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and helping out her husband in meeting household needs.

loans.use: to purchase traditional 'pagne' cloth

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les quatre femmes du groupe Benkola  ont  en moyenne 41 ans et 9 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier DALLAN de San  dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et de parenté. Elles font l’achat et la vente  de tissus  et des articles divers. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  2 eme prêt solidaire.
Madame,  ASSAN  (1ere personne  debout de la gauche vers droite) compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  6 pièces de wax et 6 complets de Bazin  elle s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame ASSAN espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
All of them married in traditional extended families, the four women of the group Benkola average 41 years of age and nine children each. The women all live in the DALLAN de San district, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali), and they know one another through ties of community, marriage, and kinship. They buy and sell fabrics and a variety of items. 

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan. 

Ms. ASSAN (first person standing from the left in the photo) intends to use her loan to purchase 6 lengths of Wax 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa) and 6 damask outfits. She gets her supplies from wholesalers. Accepting cash, she makes her sales to a customer base composed of men and women. 

With this loan, Ms. ASSAN hopes to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting household needs.

loans.use: to purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Luisa Mirella

texts.es:
Luisa es una joven madre de 21 años, su pequeño tiene 3 años de edad, a quien quiere muchísimo y trabaja muy duro para poder sacarlo adelante, y poder ofrecer mejores oportunidades que las que tuvo. Luisa debido a los pocos recursos económicos solo pudo estudiar hasta el tercer grado de secundaria, debido a los pocos recursos económicos de sus padres, pero le hubiera encantado estudiar la carrera de diseño de modas. 

Día a día Luisa trabaja como vigilante en una empresa, ella labora alrededor de 9 horas al día y también vende ropa con lo cual tiene un ingreso extra para su hogar, ella cree que está saliendo adelante porque es honrada y tiene mucha fe en Dios.

Luisa está muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda que le están brindando el podrá comprar mercadería para el día de la madre como chompas, pantalones, entre otros; de esta manera ella podrá mejorar sus ingresos y seguir trabajando para poder hacer realidad su más grande sueño:” Tener un local propio para su negocio y darle una profesión a su hijo”.
texts.en:
Luisa is a young, 21-year old mother.  Her little one is 3 years old; she loves him dearly and works very hard to get him ahead and to be able to offer him better opportunities than she had.

Due to scarce economic resources, Luisa was only able to study until the third year of secondary school, but she would have loved to study fashion design.

Day after day, Luisa works as a guard at a business.  She works around 9 hours a day and also sells clothing, with which she gets extra income for her home.  She believes she is getting ahead because she is honest and has a lot of faith in God.

Luis is very grateful to the Kiva lenders, because thanks to the assistance that they are providing her, she will be able to buy merchandise for Mother's Day, like sweaters, pants, and others.  In this way, she will be able to improve her income and continue working in order to realize her greatest dream:  "To have her own store for her business and to give her son a profession."

loans.use: to buy merchandise (shirts, sweaters, among others).

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato is 38 years old and single. He lives in Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. 

To earn a living, he owns and operates a banana production in the local community. He has been in his business for over six years and earns PHP 2,000, every month. 

Renato joined Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) in 2010 and now he has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase chemicals for farming.   In the future, Renato wants to make improvements to his house and to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase chemicals for farming.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les femmes du groupe Danaya ont  en moyenne 46 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier de Dallan de San, dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités professionnelles et de parenté. Elles font l’achat et la vente de produits cosmétiques, de tasses plastiques et de diverses marchandises. 
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles de plus en plus nombreuses et exigeantes, les membres du groupe ont décidé  d’intégrer  le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  5 eme  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les prêts  précédents.
Madame,   FAFOUNE présidente de l’association (3 eme femme de la droite vers la gauche) excelle dans la vente de cosmétiques et de bijoux. Elle est très sollicitée dans le quartier  de DALLAN et ses environnants. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, deux douzaines de parfums, 5 douzaines de crème pour la peau et une certaines quantité de bijoux à Bamako.  Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle mixtes. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame  FAFOUNE  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen
 de 16500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et  aider son conjoint dans la prise en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Married mainly in traditional extended families, the women of the group Danaya are on average 46 years old and have 3 children. They all live in the Dallan de San neighborhood, in the region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali) and met through neighborhood, professional business and family ties. They buy and sell cosmetics, plastic cups and a variety of merchandise. With the goal of satisfying the needs of their more and more numerous and demanding clientele, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 5th loan in solidarity, after having correctly repaid the previous loans.

Madam Fafoune, president of the association (3rd woman from the right to the left) excels in the sale of cosmetics and jewelry. She is very much in demand in her neighborhood of Dallan and its surroundings.

She plans to use her loan to buy 2 dozen perfumes, 5 dozen skin creams and a certain quantity of jewelry in Bamako. She carries out her sales for cash, retail and for credit to a mixed clientele.

With this loan, Madam Fafoune hopes to make an average monthly profit of 16,500 FCFA which will be used to be reinvested in her business and to help her spouse to take care of the needs of the home.

loans.use: to buy a variety of items.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les cinq femmes du groupe Benkadi  ont  en moyenne 36 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes  le quartier DALLAN de San dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités professionnelles et de parenté. Elles font l’achat et la vente de fruits et légumes et de boissons. 
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles de plus en plus croissantes  et exigeantes, les membres du groupe ont décidé  d’intégrer  le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  2e prêt solidaire.
Madame ASSAN (deuxième debout de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo) excelle dans la vente de fruits et légumes  de tous genres. Elle est très sollicitée dans les différentes foires qu’elle fréquente.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 10  sacs de pomme de terre  2 paniers de tomate, 3 sacs de banane plantain, 1 panier de poivron. Elle s’approvisionne avec les grossistes venant de Sikasso hebdomadairement. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail  à une clientèle mixtes dans plusieurs foires du cercle de SAN. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame ASSAN espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et  aider son conjoint dans la prise en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Married for the most part in traditional extended families, the five women of the group Benkadi average 36 years of age and four children each. The women all live in the DALLAN de San district, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and know one another through ties of community, professional work, and kinship. They buy and sell fruit & vegetables and beverages.

With the goal of satisfying the needs of their burgeoning and demanding customer base, the group members decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan. 

Ms. ASSAN (second person standing from the right in the photo) excels in selling fruit & vegetables of all sorts. She is much in demand at the different fairs that she attends. She intends to use her loan to purchase 10 sacks of potatoes, 2 baskets of tomatoes, 3 sacks of plantains, and a basket of bell peppers. She gets her supplies from wholesalers from Sikasso each week. Accepting cash, she makes her sales retail to a mixed customer base at the many fairs in Cercle de SAN.

With this loan, Ms. ASSAN hopes to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will used for reinvesting in her business and helping out her husband in meeting household needs.

loans.use: to purchase fruit & vegetables

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 30 years old, married, and has three children. Her children are between the ages of 8 and 16 years old. 

Fatmata runs her general store in Port Loko, which is in the northern area of Sierra Leone. She began this business in 2003.  Since she did not go to school, operating a store was her best option. She sells fish, onions, palm oil, soap, and milk at her house. Her main business challenge is transporting the goods to her house.

Fatmata is requesting this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy fish, onions, palm oil, soap, and milk to sell at her store. The extra income she will earn as a result of this loan will help her to improve her business and educate her children. In the future, she would like to have a big shop. 

She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy fish, onions, palm oil, soap, and milk.

loans.name: Saramaya Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les six femmes du groupe  SARAMAYA   ont  en moyenne 35 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Lafiabougou  cercle de SAN dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles font la restauration et le commerce d’articles divers. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont adhéré  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  1er   prêt solidaire.
Madame, KOUMBA (1ere  femme debout de la  droite vers la  gauche) excelle dans la vente de savons et divers articles  depuis plus de 10 ans,  très sollicitée dans le quartier.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 5 sacs de savons et beaucoup d’autres articles divers tels le bleu pour les habits et de l’amidon elle s’approvisionne à SAN. Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame KOUMBA espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et  aider son conjoint dans la prise en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
All of them married in traditional extended families, the six women of the group SARAMAYA average 35 years of age and five children each. The women all live in the Lafiabougou district, in Cercle de SAN, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali), and they know one another through ties of community and kinship. They work in food service and in selling a variety of items. 

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan. 

Ms. KOUMBA (first woman standing from the right in the photo) has excelled in selling soaps and various goods for over ten years and is much in demand in the district. She intends to use her loan to purchase 5 sacks of soaps and many other items, such as 'bleu' for clothing and some starch. She gets her supplies in SAN. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales to a customer base composed of men and women. 

With this loan, Ms. KOUMBA hopes to make an average monthly profit of 18,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting household needs.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of goods, such as soap, to sell

loans.name: Henry Benjamin

texts.es:
Benjamín  tiene 35 años de edad es soltero vive con sus padres en el Cantón  Chillanes Provincia Bolívar.



Es integrante de ventanilla Unión Central Parroquia San José del  Tambo actividad económica agricultura, 

crianza de animales  y comercio la comunidad se encuentra a una hora de la cooperativa.



Benjamín se dedica a la agricultura a la limpieza de huertas.   


Solicita el crédito para la limpieza de las huertas de cacao y mejorar la producción.  



Las compras lo realizan en San José Del Tambo. Su sueño es realizar su casa propia.  



No tiene ningún desafío que enfrentar.  



En el tiempo libre le gusta trabajar.
texts.en:
Benjamin is 35 years old, single and lives with his parents in the Chillanes Canton in the Bolivar province. He is a member of the communal bank "Union Central Parroquia San Jose", which focuses on agricultural, animal breeding and commercial activities. The community is located one hour away from the communal bank.
Benjamin works cleaning crop fields. He is asking for this loan to clean cocoa fields in order to improve production. The purchases will be carried out in San Jose del Tambo.
His dream is to build his own house. He faces no particular challenges.
In his spare time he likes to work.

loans.use: to clean cocoa fields and improve production.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
This is Nancy, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is a widow and a mother to her children. She, together with her children, manages their household while operating a business. She and her children are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

Nancy maintains a direct-selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics, and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, and Marikina Shoe Exchange. 

In direct-sales, a customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s costs are lower than the prices in the catalogue, and the difference represents the profit that dealers are investing as their income. 

Nancy's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales, every week.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products, like shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, and undergarments. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Nancy dreams that her business will expand continually and that she will have other sources of income. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise products to sell in her direct-sales business.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is married and she works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from food-vending. Jean is borrowing PHP 14,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to purchase more items, like soft drinks, canned goods, and other groceries.

Jean has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money, to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items like soft-drinks, canned goods, and other groceries.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les quatre  femmes du groupe  DJIGUIYA  ont  en moyenne 39 ans et  6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village DIELI cercle SAN  dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et de parenté. Elles font la vente de divers articles et de savons. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur  3e prêt solidaire.
Madame, MARATOU  (2e  personne debout  de  la droite vers la gauche) excelle  dans la vente de savons de fabrication artisanale et industrielle et elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 8 sacs de kabakourouni et 10 sacs de BT et fanico.    Elle s’approvisionne  auprès des grossistes de SAN et effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, à domicile  et à la foire de DIELI  tous les jeudis. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame MARATOU  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
All of them married in traditional extended families, the four women of the group DJIGUIYA average 39 years of age and six children each. The women all live in the village of DIELI district, in Cercle de SAN, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali), and they know one another through ties of community, marriage, and kinship. They sell a variety of goods and soaps. 

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third solidarity loan. 

Ms. MARATOU (second person standing from the right in the photo) excels in selling commercial and artisanal soaps, and she intends to use her loan to purchase 8 sacks of 'kabakourouni' and 10 sacks of 
BT et fanico. She gets her supplies from SAN wholesalers. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales at home and at the DIELI fair each Thursday. Her customer base is composed of men and women. 

With this loan, Ms. MARATOU hopes to make an average monthly profit of 22,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting household needs.

loans.use: to purchase soaps

loans.name: Apec Ai Ouma Sicap Mbao Gpe  3 Group

texts.fr: Le sous-groupe APEC AL OUMA G3 est  un démembrement  du groupement d’intérêt économique AL OUMA. Il est constitué de 10 femmes qui s’activent toutes dans le secteur du commerce. Elles habitent aussi   dans la même localité et sont représentées par madame  Néné (personne qui  a levé la main sur la photo). Elle est spécialisée dans la vente de draps de lits. Elle a une double activité et s’adonne aussi a la restauration depuis  10 ans. Elle est sociétaire de l’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC, ou  elle sollicite  un crédit qui ’elle   sera utilisé d’une part  pour renforcer son stock de drap et d’autre part  pour s’approvisionner en denrées alimentaires pour son activité de   restauration. Par conséquent ce financement pourra l’appuyer a  mieux développer ses activités économiques. La rentabilité de ce projet lui permettra ainsi de démarrer la vente d’huile de palme, d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et d’épargner plus d’argent. Elle souhaite prochainement agrandir  son restaurant  ouvrir une boutique pour la vente de tissus.
texts.en:
The sub-group APEC AL OUMA G3 is a remnant of the economic interest group AL OUMA. It is composed of ten women who are all active in commerce. They also live in the same town and are represented by Ms. Néné (with her hand raised in the photo). She is specialized in selling bed sheets. She has had a second business for ten years devoting her time to food service. 

She is an associate of a U-IMCEC branch, where she is requesting a loan she will use in part to bolster her stock of bed sheets, as well as to stock up on food items for her restaurant business. So, this financing will help her to develop her business activity further. The profitability of this project will thus enable her to start selling palm oil, improve her family's living conditions, and save more money. She would like to expand her restaurant soon and open a store for selling fabrics.

loans.use: to purchase bed sheets to sell

loans.name: Olivia Evangelina

texts.es:
Olivia, posee una pupuseria. Ella está soltera, no tiene hijos y no recibe ayuda del extranjero; este oficio lo realiza como una fuente generadora de ingresos para tener una mejor calidad de vida, esta actividad la lleva a cabo de 4:00 pm a 9:00 pm y lo aprendió de su familia.
El crédito le permitirá comprar maíz, chicharrón, repollo, vinagre, entre otros productos; este le permitirá mejorar su negocio, atraer más clientela y también optimizar sus ventas.
Su sueño es ampliar el local  y asimismo generar mas ganancias.
texts.en:
Olivia owns a small Pupusa (stuffed tortillas) stand. She is a single woman with no children and she does not receive any remittances. Olivia learned to make Pupusas from her parents and now she depends on her Pupusa stand to make a living. She works daily from 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. 

This loan will help Olivia to buy corn, pork rinds, cabbage, vinegar, and other products. These will help her to improve her business, optimize sales, and attract new customers. Her dream is to expand her business and generate more income.

loans.use: to buy corn, pork rinds, cabbage, vinegar, and other products.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, les cinq femmes du groupe DANAYA  ont  en moyenne 36 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village  de DIELI  dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités professionnelles et de parenté. Elles font la  restauration, et la vente de divers articles. 
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles de plus en plus nombreuses et exigeantes, les membres du groupe ont décidé  d’intégrer  le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur 3eme  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les prêts précédents.
Madame,   SAFOURA  (debout au milieu  sur la photo) excelle dans la restauration. Elle est très sollicitée dans à la foire de  DIELI   et  environnants car elle  fait de très bons plats.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 2 sacs de riz décortiqué un bidon de 20 litres d’huile et divers autres condiments.  Elle effectue ses ventes au comptant, en détail  à une clientèle mixte. 
Avec ce prêt, Madame SAFOURA  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen
 De 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et  aider son conjoint dans la prise en charge des besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Married for the most part in traditional extended families, the five women of the group DANAYA average 36 years of age and three children each. The women all live in the village of DIELI, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and know one another through ties of community, professional work, and kinship. They work in food service and in selling a variety of goods.
